block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Sailing the Harbor: Alice's Tall Ships,'' photographs by Alice Austin 100 years ago; through Sept. 3. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Sailing the Harbor: Alice's Tall Ships,'' photographs by Alice Austin 100 years ago; through Sept. 3. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be An Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8 p.m. with Ron Affif, through July 28. Free with admission; food and cash bar. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. This weekend completes Military Salute Week, featuring tall ships and live demonstrations. Weekend activities include a tug-of-war tournament (today at 12:30 p.m.); best chow competition (tomorrow at 2 p.m.); searchsand rescue demonstrations (various times throughout the weekend); a parachute demonstration (today at noon and 5 p.m. and tomorrow at 3 p.m.). Admission: $12; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; ages 2 to 5, $2; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072. Special hours this weekend: today and tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Sunday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. ''Firecrackers: Chinatown Today,'' photographic works by Andrew Garn mounted on light boxes; through next Friday. Admission: $8 adults; $6 students and seniors. Guided tours: Monday through Fridays, every hour from 1 to 4:00 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m. until the last tour at 4:30 p.m. Museum hours: Mondays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tour prices: $9; students, the elderly and children over 5, $7; children 5 and under, free. Special prices for two and three tours. Information: (212) 431-0233.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Other exhibitions: ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, Alexander Hamilton United States Customs House, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan. ''Reservation X: The Power of Place,'' multimedia installations by seven artists, through Aug. 20.Daily screenings in the video viewing room begin at 1 p.m. and are repeated on Thursdays at 5:30 p.m. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 514-3888.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Stork Club,'' including an environmental installation that mimics the floor plan of the club, photographs and memorabilia belonging to the family of Sherman Billingsley, the owner of the club; on view through Oct. 1. ''Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography in America,'' images from the 1870's through the 1950's, through Aug. 13. ''The Changing Face of Liberty: Female Allegories of America,'' featuring color lithographs, posters, political cartoons and drawings; through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. Beginning Sunday, the opening of a special self-guided trail of the butterflies and hummingbirds that inhabit the garden, with related crafts and other activities on weekends through Sept. 16. Through Sunday in the Steinhardt Gallery, ''Glass Flowers by Paul Stankard: A Floral Tribute to Walt Whitman.'' Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The Exotic Courtyard Garden is open through Sept. 24. Tomorrow visitors can consult plant information experts in the library beginning at noon with questions and meet at the Great Garden Clock at 2 p.m. for a tour of the Perennial Garden. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Garden and summer Adventure Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. ''Animals as Architects,''a hands-on science exhibition through Aug. 31; and ''Summer Train Show,'' through Sept. 10, with model trains built into the landscape; both in the Children's Adventure Garden. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5.Information: (718) 817-8700.
Zoos

BRONX ZOO, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham. Some 265 wooded acres are devoted to naturalistic habitats, including Jungle World, African Plains, the Baboon Reserve, the World of Birds, the Aitken Sea Bird Colony (with daily penguin feedings at 3:30 p.m.), Big Birds and the Congo Gorilla Forest (Admission: $3). The Butterfly Zone has reopened through Oct. 1, with thousands of butterflies and moths and an area where visitors can see the metamorphosis of chrysalides, or cocoons, into butterflies or moths, weather permitting. (Admission: $2.) The zoo shuttle, skyfari and the children's zoo are open through Oct. 29. The Bengali Express Monorail (admission: $2) is open, passing Asian elephants, tigers, red pandas and other exotic animals. Through Sept. 30, daily tours; reservations necessary: (718) 220-5141. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. General admission, $9; $5 for children 2 to 12 and the elderly; free general admission for everyone on Wednesdays. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 367-1010.
Cruises

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speed boat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., 11 a.m., noon, 1 p.m., 2, 3 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.
EVENTS
PUBLIC VIEWING OF TALL SHIPS AT SOUTH STREET SEAPORT, Lower Manhattan. Today and tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Ships depart Sunday, beginning at 10 a.m. Free.

''SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Featuring a trio of percussionists: Mary Knysh, Peter Hawes and Pamela Patrick. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

UKRAINIAN DANCE PERFORMANCE, Battery Park City, Esplanade Plaza, adjacent to the North Cove Yacht Harbor, south of the World Financial Center. With live music and performances by members of Voloshky, a troupe, as well as dance workshops. Tomorrow at 6:30 p.m. Sponsored by the Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

RIVERMUSIC FESTIVAL, Chelsea Piers, Pier 62, Hudson River and 23rd Street. A monthly music festival that runs through September, with each installment offering a different form of music. Tomorrow at 6 p.m.: ''A Little Bit of Country.'' Tickets, $10; free for children under 16. There will also be free concerts tomorrow and Sunday at noon. Information: (212) 336-6881.
RECREATION

CITYWIDE BEACH VOLLEYBALL TOURNAMENT. . The preliminary competitions featuring mixed-sex and single-sex teams, will be held tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on the east side of Central Park, between the Sheep Meadow and the band shell; in Riverside Park, off 105th Street; Coney Island and West 10th Street, Brooklyn; sections 10 and 11 at Orchard Beach, the Bronx; Rockaway Beach at 86th Street, Queens; off Sand Boulevard, South Beach, Staten Island. The championships and a beach party are planned Sunday at 10 a.m. at Coney Island. Sponsored by the city's Parks and Recreation Department and 2000 Ford Explorer. Free. Registration and information: (212) 360-8222.

PHS HEALTH PLANS BRONX HALF-MARATHON, streets of the North Bronx. A 13.1-mile run on Sunday beginning at 8 a.m. at Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior members. Same-day registration: $22; $15 for members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
ON THE STREET
SUMMER SEAPORT FESTIVAL, Water Street, from Fulton to Wall Streets, Lower Manhattan. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Downtown Republican Club.
AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS FESTIVAL, Avenue of the Americas, from 14th to 23rd Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the McBurney Y.M.C.A.

U.S.O.-AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS SUMMERFEST, Avenue of the Americas, from 42nd to 57th Streets. There will be entertainment, as well as food and crafts. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the U.S.O. of Metropolitan New York.
WALKING TOURS

''DUMBO'S INDUSTRIAL PAST AND CONTESTED FUTURE,'' Brooklyn. A tour of the historic waterfront area led by Tom Flagg, an archaeologist, and Dan Wiley, an educator. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. at Old Fulton Street and the East River, opposite the River Cafe. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for Center members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''FIFTH AVENUE GOLD COAST,'' Upper East Side. Explore the mansions to the east of Central Park. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''LATE FOR THE SKY: THE HIGH-RISE SINCE 1975,'' Midtown Manhattan. Examines the buildings of Gordon Bunshaft, Helmut Jahn, I. M. Pei and Christian de Portzamparc. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for Society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''STANFORD WHITE: SPLENDOR AND SCANDAL,'' Lower Manhattan. Looks at the life of the architect and the buildings he designed. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m. at the Washington Arch. Fee, $15. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''AMERICAN REVOLUTION TOUR AND OPSAIL 2000 VIEWING, Lower Manhattan. A tour of sites associated with people and events of the Revolution, including Trinity Church, Federal Hall and Fraunces Tavern. There will be time after tomorrow's tour to board tall ships and, on Sunday, to watch some of the ships depart. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. and Sunday at 1 p.m. Fee: $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Information: (212) 465-3331.

''MANHATTAN MOVIE MEMORIES.'' Places seen in movies like ''The Out-of-Towners'' and ''Sea of Love.'' Tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m. and 2:15 p.m. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Fee: $11. Meeting place: (212) 629-1886.

''BEAUTY UNDERFOOT: MANHOLE COVERS IN BROOKLYN HEIGHTS.'' A tour of historic covers led by Diana Stuart, a photographer and historian. Meets Sunday at 11 a.m. at the intersection of Clinton and Montague Streets. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for member of the Center; $5 for children and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

HISTORIC (OLD) NEW YORK CITY WALKING TOUR, Lower Manhattan. Includes such places as the financial district, Fraunces Tavern, the Vietnam Memorial and Battery Park. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. on the northeast corner of Fulton Street and Broadway. Fee, $10. Sponsored by New York City Cultural Walking Tours. Information: (212) 979-2388.

''AFFLUENT ENCLAVE: BEEKMAN PLACE-SUTTON PLACE,'' Manhattan. The tour stops at River House, the Abigail Adams Smith Museum and the former residences of Irving Berlin, Greta Garbo and Rex Harrison. Meets Sunday at 3 p.m. on the northwest corner of 52nd Street and First Avenue. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

SILVER AND CLOVE LAKES PARK, Staten Island. A five-mile walk that meets tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. at the Manhattan terminal of the Staten Island Ferry. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Fee, $3. Information: (718) 420-9569.

''THE AMERICAN INDIAN HERITAGE OF MANHATTAN ISLAND: FROM WAMPUM TO WALL STREET,'' Lower Manhattan. Traces the interaction of American Indians with Dutch and English settlers. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. inside Blimpie's, 38 Park Row, between Beekman and Spruce Streets. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''WALKS IN OLD CHELSEA.'' A look at the stately buildings of the area and the stories behind them. Meets on Sunday at 2 p.m. in front of the Flatiron Building, Broadway and 23rd Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. A tour that includes stops at a church and several cultural institutions. Meets on Sunday at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
